Uncertainty Principle for Communication Compression in Distributed and Federated Learning and the Search for an Optimal Compressor

Mher Safaryan â€ƒâ€ƒEgor Shulgin111Part of this work was done by the author as a student at the Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology, Dolgoprudny, Russia. â€ƒâ€ƒPeter RichtÃ¡rik
XXX
King Abdullah University of Science and Technology
Thuwal, Saudi Arabia
(26 / 1 / 2021)
Abstract

In order to mitigate the high communication cost in distributed and federated learning, various vector compression schemes, such as quantization, sparsification and dithering, have become very popular. In designing a compression method, one aims to communicate as few bits as possible, which minimizes the cost per communication round, while at the same time attempting to impart as little distortion (variance) to the communicated messages as possible, which minimizes the adverse effect of the compression on the overall number of communication rounds. However, intuitively, these two goals are fundamentally in conflict: the more compression we allow, the more distorted the messages become. We formalize this intuition and prove an uncertainty principle for randomized compression operators, thus quantifying this limitation mathematically, and effectively providing asymptotically tight lower bounds on what might be achievable with communication compression. Motivated by these developments, we call for the search for the optimal compression operator. In an attempt to take a first step in this direction, we consider an unbiased compression method inspired by the Kashin representation of vectors, which we call Kashin compression (KC). In contrast to all previously proposed compression mechanisms, KC enjoys a dimension independent variance bound for which we derive an explicit formula even in the regime when only a few bits need to be communicate per each vector entry.

1 Introduction

In the quest for high accuracy machine learning models, both the size of the model and consequently the amount of data necessary to train the model have been hugely increased over time (Schmidhuber, 2015; Vaswani u.â€‰a., 2019). Because of this, performing the learning process on a single machine is often infeasible. In a typical scenario of distributed learning, the training data (and possibly the model as well) is spread across different machines and thus the process of training is done in a distributed manner (Bekkerman u.â€‰a., 2011; Vogels u.â€‰a., 2019). Another scenario, most common to federated learning (KoneÄnÃ½ u.â€‰a., 2016; McMahan u.â€‰a., 2017; Karimireddy u.â€‰a., 2019a), is when training data is inherently distributed across a large number of mobile edge devices due to data privacy concerns.

1.1 Communication bottleneck

In all cases of distributed learning and federated learning, information (e.g. current stochastic gradient vector or current state of the model) communication between computing nodes is inevitable, which forms the primary bottleneck of such systems (Zhang u.â€‰a., 2017; Lin u.â€‰a., 2018). This issue is especially apparent in federated learning, where computing nodes are devices with essentially inferior power and the network bandwidth is considerably slow (Li u.â€‰a., 2019).

There are two general approaches to address/tackle this problem. One line of research dedicated to so-called local methods suggests to do more computational work before each communication in the hope that those would increase the worth/impact/value of the information to be communicated (Goyal u.â€‰a., 2017; Wangni u.â€‰a., 2018; Stich, 2018; Khaled u.â€‰a., 2020). An alternative approach investigates inexact/lossy information compression strategies which aim to send approximate but relevant information encoded with less number of bits. In this work we focus on the second approach of compressed learning. Research in this latter stream splits into two orthogonal directions. To explore savings in communication, various (mostly randomized) compression operators have been proposed and analyzed such as random sparsification (KoneÄnÃ½ und RichtÃ¡rik, 2018; Wangni u.â€‰a., 2018), Top-kğ‘˜k sparsification (Alistarh u.â€‰a., 2018), standard random dithering (Goodall, 1951; Roberts, 1962; Alistarh u.â€‰a., 2017), natural dithering (HorvÃ¡th u.â€‰a., 2019a), ternary quantization (Wen u.â€‰a., 2017), and sign quantization (Karimireddy u.â€‰a., 2019b; Bernstein u.â€‰a., 2018, 2019; Liu u.â€‰a., 2019; Safaryan und RichtÃ¡rik, 2019). TableÂ 1 summarizes the most common compression methods with their variances and the number of encoding bits.

In designing a compression operator, one aims to (i) encode the compressed information with as few bits as possible, which minimizes the cost per communication round, and (ii) introduce as little noise (variance) to the communicated messages as possible, which minimizes the adverse effect of the compression on the overall iteration complexity.

1.2 Compressed learning

In order to utilize these compression methods efficiently, a lot of research has been devoted to the study of learning algorithms with compressed communication. Obviously, the presence of compression in a learning algorithm affects the training process and since compression operator encodes the original information approximately, it should be anticipated to increase the number of communication rounds. TableÂ 2 highlights four gradient-type compressed learning algorithms with their corresponding setup and iteration complexity:

  • (i)

    distributed Gradient Descent (GD) with compressed gradients (Khirirat u.â€‰a., 2018),

  • (ii)

    distributed Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) with gradient quantization and compression variance reduction (HorvÃ¡th u.â€‰a., 2019b),

  • (iii)

    distributed SGD with bi-directional gradient compression (HorvÃ¡th u.â€‰a., 2019a), and

  • (iv)

    distributed SGD with gradient compression and twofold error compensation (Tang u.â€‰a., 2019).

In all cases, the iteration complexity depends on the variance of the underlying compression scheme and grows as more compression is applied. For this reason, we are interested in compression methods which save in communication by using less bits and minimize iteration complexity by introducing lower variance. However, intuitively and also evidently from TableÂ 1, these two goals are in fundamental conflict, i.e. requiring fewer bits to be communicated in each round introduces higher variance, and demanding small variance forces more bits to be communicated.

1.3 Contributions

We make the following contributions in this work:

Uncertainty Principle. We formalize this intuitive trade-off and prove an uncertainty principle for randomized compression operators, which quantifies this limitation mathematically with the inequality

Î±â‹…4b/dâ‰¥1,â‹…ğ›¼superscript4ğ‘ğ‘‘1\alpha\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1, (1)

where Î±âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1] is the normalized variance (or contraction factor) associated with the compression operator (DefinitionÂ 1), bğ‘b is the number of bits required to encode the compressed vector and dğ‘‘d is the dimension of the vector to be compressed. It is a universal property of compressed communication, completely independent of the optimization algorithm and the problem that distributed training is trying to solve. We visualize this principle in FigureÂ 1, where many possible combinations of parameters Î±ğ›¼\alpha and b/dğ‘ğ‘‘\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}} were computed for various compression methods. The dashed red line, indicating the lower bound (1), bounds all possible combinations of all compression operators, thus validating the obtained uncertainty principle for randomized compression operators. We also show that this lower bound is asymptotically tight.

Kashin Compression. Motivated by this principle, we then focus on the search for the optimal compression operator. In an attempt to take a first step in this direction, we investigate an unbiased compression operator inspired by Kashin representation of vectorsÂ (Kashin, 1977), which we call Kashin Compression (KC). In contrast to all previously proposed compression methods, KC enjoys a dimension independent variance bound even in a severe compression regime when only a few bits per coordinate can be communicated. We derive an explicit formula for the variance bound. Furthermore, we experimentally observed the superiority of KC in terms of communication savings and stabilization property when compared against commonly used compressors proposed in the literature. In particular, FigureÂ 1 justifies that KC combined with Top-kğ‘˜k sparsification and dithering operators yields a compression method which is the most efficient scheme when communication is scarce. Kashinâ€™s representation has been used heuristically in the context of federated learning (Caldas u.â€‰a., 2019) to mitigate the communication cost. We believe KC should be of high interest in federated and distributed learning.

2 Uncertainty principle for compression operators

In general, an uncertainty principle refers to any type of mathematical inequality expressing some fundamental trade-off between two measurements. The classical Heisenbergâ€™s uncertainty principle in quantum mechanicsÂ (Heisenberg, 1927) shows the trade-off between the position and momentum of a particle. In harmonic analysis, the uncertainty principle limits the localization of values of a function and its Fourier transform at the same timeÂ (Havin und JÃ¶ricke, 1994). Alternatively in the context of signal processing, signals cannot be simultaneously localized in both time domain and frequency domainÂ (Gabor, 1946). The uncertainty principle in communication deals with the quite intuitive trade-off between information compression (encoding bits) and approximation error (variance), namely more compression forces heavier distortion to communicated messages and tighter approximation requires less information compression.

In this section, we present our UP for communication compression revealing the trade-off between encoding bits of compressed information and the variance produced by compression operator. First, we describe UP for some general class of biased compressions. Afterwards, we specialize it to the class of unbiased compressions.

2.1 UP for biased compressions

We work with the class of biased compression operators which are contractive.

Definition 1 (Biased Compressions)

Let ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha) be the class of biased (and possibly randomized) compression operators ğ’:â„dâ†’â„d:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}\colon\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} with Î±âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1] contractive property, i.e. for any xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’â€‹(x)âˆ’xâ€–22]â‰¤Î±â€‹â€–xâ€–22.ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnormğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥22ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¥22\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\alpha\|x\|_{2}^{2}. (2)

The parameter Î±ğ›¼\alpha can be seen as the normalized variance of the compression operator. Note that the compression ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} does not need to be randomized to belong to this class. For instance, Top-kğ‘˜k sparsification operator satisfies (2) without the expectation for Î±=1âˆ’kdğ›¼1ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\alpha=1-\frac{k}{d}. Next, we formalize uncertainty principle for the class ğ”¹â€‹(Î±)ğ”¹ğ›¼\mathbb{B}(\alpha).

Î±â‹…4b/dâ‰¥1.â‹…ğ›¼superscript4ğ‘ğ‘‘1\alpha\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1. (3)

One can view the binary32 and binary64 floating-points formats as biased compression methods for the actual real numbers (i.e. d=1ğ‘‘1d=1), using only 32 and 64 bits respectively to represent a single number. Intuitively, these formats have their precision (i.e. Î±ğ›¼\sqrt{\alpha}) limits and the uncertainty principle (3) shows that the precision cannot be better than 2âˆ’32superscript2322^{-32} for binary32 format and 2âˆ’64superscript2642^{-64} for binary64 format. Thus, any floating-point format representing a single number with rğ‘Ÿr bits has precision constraint of 2âˆ’rsuperscript2ğ‘Ÿ2^{-r}, where the base 222 stems from the binary nature of the bit.

Furthermore, notice that compression operators can achieve zero variance in some settings, e.g. ternary or scaled sign quantization when d=1ğ‘‘1d=1 (see Table 1). On the other hand, the UP (3) implies that the normalized variance Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0 for any finite bits bğ‘b. The reason for this inconsistency comes from the fact that, for instance, the binary32 format encodes any number with 32 bits and the error 2âˆ’32superscript2322^{-32} is usually ignored in practice. We can adjust UP to any digital format, using rğ‘Ÿr bits per single number, as

(Î±+4âˆ’r)â€‹4b/dâ‰¥1.ğ›¼superscript4ğ‘Ÿsuperscript4ğ‘ğ‘‘1\left(\alpha+4^{-r}\right)4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1. (4)

3 Compression with polytopes

Here we describe an unbiased compression scheme based on polytopes. With this particular compression we illustrate that it is possible for unbiased compressions to have dimension independent variance bounds and at the same time communicate a single bits per coordinate.

Let xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} be nonzero vector that we need to encode. First, we project the vector on the unit sphere

ğ•Šdâˆ’1={xâˆˆâ„d:â€–xâ€–2=1},superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1conditional-setğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptnormğ‘¥21\mathbb{S}^{d-1}=\{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\|x\|_{2}=1\},

thus separating the magnitude â€–xâ€–2âˆˆâ„subscriptnormğ‘¥2â„\|x\|_{2}\in\mathbb{R} from the direction x/â€–xâ€–2âˆˆğ•Šdâˆ’1ğ‘¥subscriptnormğ‘¥2superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1x/\|x\|_{2}\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}. The magnitude is a dimension independent scalar value and we can transfer it cheaply, say by 32 bits. To encode the unit vector x/â€–xâ€–2ğ‘¥subscriptnormğ‘¥2x/\|x\|_{2} we approximate the unit sphere by polytopes and then randomize over the vertices of the polytope. Polytopes can be seen as generalizations of planar polygons in high dimensions. Formally, let Pmsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘šP_{m} be a polytope with vertices {v1,v2,â€¦,vm}âŠ‚â„dsubscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\{v_{1},v_{2},\dots,v_{m}\}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} such that it contains the unit sphere, i.e. ğ•Šdâˆ’1âŠ‚Pmsuperscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘š\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\subset P_{m}, and all vertices are on the sphere of radius R>1ğ‘…1R>1. Then, any unit vector vâˆˆğ•Šdâˆ’1ğ‘£superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1v\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1} can be expressed as a convex combination âˆ‘k=1mwkâ€‹vksuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘£ğ‘˜\sum_{k=1}^{m}w_{k}v_{k} with some non-negative weights wk=wkâ€‹(x)subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜ğ‘¥w_{k}=w_{k}(x). Therefore, the direction x/â€–xâ€–2ğ‘¥subscriptnormğ‘¥2x/\|x\|_{2} could be encoded with roughly logâ¡mğ‘š\log m bits and the variance Ï‰ğœ”\omega of compression will depend on the approximation, more specifically Ï‰=R2âˆ’1ğœ”superscriptğ‘…21\omega=R^{2}-1. In Kochol (2004, 1994) it is given a constructive proof on approximation of the dğ‘‘d-dimensional unit sphere by polytopes with mâ‰¥2â€‹dğ‘š2ğ‘‘m\geq 2d vertices for which Ï‰=ğ’ªâ€‹(dlogâ¡m/d)ğœ”ğ’ªğ‘‘ğ‘šğ‘‘\omega={\cal O}\left(\tfrac{d}{\log\nicefrac{{m}}{{d}}}\right). So, choosing the number of vertices to be m=2dğ‘šsuperscript2ğ‘‘m=2^{d}, one gets an unbiased compression operator with ğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğ’ª1{\cal O}(1) variance (independent of dimension dğ‘‘d) and with 1 bit per coordinate encoding.

This simple method does not seem to be practical as 2dsuperscript2ğ‘‘2^{d} vertices of the polytope either need to be stored or computed each time they are used, which is infeasible for large dimensions. However, we use this construction and show that lower bounds (6) and hence (3) are asymptotically tight.

4 Compression with Kashinâ€™s representation

In this section we review the notion of Kashinâ€™s representation, the algorithm in Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010) on computing it efficiently and then describe the quantization step.

4.1 Representation systems

The most common way of compressing a given vector xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is to use its orthogonal representation with respect to the standard basis (ei)i=1dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘‘(e_{i})_{i=1}^{d} in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}:

x=âˆ‘i=1dxiâ€‹ei,xi=âŸ¨x,eiâŸ©.formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘’ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘’ğ‘–x=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{d}x_{i}e_{i},\qquad x_{i}=\left\langle x,e_{i}\right\rangle.

However, the restriction of orthogonal expansions is that coefficients xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} are independent in the sense that if we lost one of them, then we cannot recover it even approximately. Furthermore, each coefficient xisubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–x_{i} may carry very different portion of the total information that vector xğ‘¥x contains; some coefficients may carry more information than others and thus be more sensitive to compression.

For this reason, it is preferable to use tight frames and frame representations instead. Tight frames are generalizations of orthonormal bases, where the system of vectors are not required to be linearly independent. Formally, vectors (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ·(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} form a tight frame if any vector xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} admits a frame representation

x=âˆ‘i=1Daiâ€‹ui,ai=âŸ¨x,uiâŸ©.formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ·subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–x=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}a_{i}u_{i},\qquad a_{i}=\left\langle x,u_{i}\right\rangle. (8)

Clearly, if D>dğ·ğ‘‘D>d (the case we are interested in), then the system (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ·(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} is linearly dependent and hence the representation (8) with coefficients aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i} is not unique. The idea is to exploit this redundancy and choose coefficients aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i} in such a way to spread the information uniformly among these coefficients. However, the frame representation may not distribute the information well enough. Thus, we need a particular representation for which coefficients aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i} have smallest possible dynamic range.

For a frame (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ·(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} define the dÃ—Dğ‘‘ğ·d\times D frame matrix Uğ‘ˆU by stacking frame vectors uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} as columns. It can be easily seen that being a tight frame is equivalent to frame matrix to be orthogonal, i.e. Uâ€‹UâŠ¤=Idğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘ˆtopsubscriptğ¼ğ‘‘UU^{\top}=I_{d}, where Idsubscriptğ¼ğ‘‘I_{d} is the dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times d identity matrix. Using the frame matrix Uğ‘ˆU, frame representation (8) takes the form x=Uâ€‹ağ‘¥ğ‘ˆğ‘x=Ua.

Definition 3 (Kashinâ€™s representation)

Let (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ·(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} be a tight frame in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}. Define Kashinâ€™s representation of xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} with level Kğ¾K the following expansion

x=âˆ‘i=1Daiâ€‹ui,max1â‰¤iâ‰¤Dâ¡|ai|â‰¤KDâ€‹â€–xâ€–2.formulae-sequenceğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ·subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscript1ğ‘–ğ·subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ¾ğ·subscriptnormğ‘¥2x=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}a_{i}u_{i},\qquad\max\limits_{1\leq i\leq D}|a_{i}|\leq\frac{K}{\sqrt{D}}\|x\|_{2}. (9)

Optimality. As noted in (Lyubarskii und Vershynin, 2010), Kashinâ€™s representation has the smallest possible dynamic range K/Dğ¾ğ·\nicefrac{{K}}{{\sqrt{D}}}, which is dğ‘‘\sqrt{d} times smaller then dynamic range of the frame representation (8).

Existence. It turns out that not every tight frame can guarantee Kashinâ€™s representation with constant level. The following existence result is based on Kashinâ€™s theorem (Kashin, 1977):

Theorem 4 (Kashin (1977))

There exist tight frames in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} with arbitrarily small redundancy Î»=D/d>1ğœ†ğ·ğ‘‘1\lambda=\nicefrac{{D}}{{d}}>1, and such that every vector xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} admits Kashinâ€™s representation with level K=Kâ€‹(Î»)ğ¾ğ¾ğœ†K=K(\lambda) that depends on Î»ğœ†\lambda only (not on dğ‘‘d or Dğ·D).

4.2 Computing Kashinâ€™s representation

To compute Kashinâ€™s representation we use the algorithm developed in Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010), which transforms the frame representation (8) into Kashinâ€™s representation (9). The algorithm requires tight frame with frame matrix satisfying the restricted isometry property:

Definition 4 (Restricted Isometry Property (RIP))

A given dÃ—Dğ‘‘ğ·d\times D matrix Uğ‘ˆU satisfies the Restricted Isometry Property with parameters Î´,Î·âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¿ğœ‚01\delta,\eta\in(0,1) if for any xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}

|suppâ€‹(x)|â‰¤Î´â€‹Dâ‡’â€–Uâ€‹xâ€–2â‰¤Î·â€‹â€–xâ€–2.formulae-sequencesuppğ‘¥ğ›¿ğ·â‡’subscriptnormğ‘ˆğ‘¥2ğœ‚subscriptnormğ‘¥2\textstyle|{\rm supp}(x)|\leq\delta D\quad\Rightarrow\quad\|Ux\|_{2}\leq\eta\|x\|_{2}. (10)

In general, for an orthogonal dÃ—Dğ‘‘ğ·d\times D matrix Uğ‘ˆU we can only guarantee the inequality â€–Uâ€‹xâ€–2â‰¤â€–xâ€–2subscriptnormğ‘ˆğ‘¥2subscriptnormğ‘¥2\|Ux\|_{2}\leq\|x\|_{2} if xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. The RIP requires Uğ‘ˆU to be a contraction mapping for sparse xğ‘¥x. With a frame matrix satisfying RIP, the analysis of Algorithm 1 from (Lyubarskii und Vershynin, 2010) yields a formula for the level of Kashinâ€™s representation:

Theorem 5 (see Theorem 3.5 of Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010))

Let (ui)i=1Dsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ·(u_{i})_{i=1}^{D} be a tight frame in â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d} which satisfies RIP with parameters Î´,Î·ğ›¿ğœ‚\delta,\eta. Then any vector xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} admits a Kashinâ€™s representation with level

K=1Î´â€‹(1âˆ’Î·).ğ¾1ğ›¿1ğœ‚K=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\delta}(1-\eta)}. (11)

4.3 Quantizing Kashinâ€™s representation

Thus, KC ğ’Îºsubscriptğ’ğœ…{\cal C}_{\kappa} with any unbiased quantization (12) belongs to ğ•Œâ€‹(K2â€‹(Î»))ğ•Œsuperscriptğ¾2ğœ†\mathbb{U}\left(K^{2}(\lambda)\right).

Described Kashin representation and Kashin compression has similarities with the Atomo framework Wang u.â€‰a. (2018), which is a general sparsification method applied on any atomic decomposition. In particular, Kashin representation x=Uâ€‹ağ‘¥ğ‘ˆğ‘x=Ua can be viewed as an atomic decomposition of xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} in lifted space â„Dsuperscriptâ„ğ·\mathbb{R}^{D}. However, in contrast to Atomo framework, we do not apply sparsification afterwards as it violates the condition (12). Instead, we utilize quantizers (e.g. coordinate-wise quantization operators) to satisfy (12), which ensures uniform and dimension-free upper bound for the variance.

5 Measure concentration and orthogonal matrices

The concentration of the measure is a remarkable high-dimensional phenomenon which roughly claims that a function defined on a high-dimensional space and having small oscillations takes values highly concentrated around the average (Ledoux, 2001; Giannopoulos und Milman, 2000). Here we present one example of such concentration for Lipschitz functions on the unit sphere, which will be the key to justify the restricted isometry property.

5.1 Concentration on the sphere for Lipschitz functions

We say that f:ğ•Šdâˆ’1â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1â„f\colon\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\to\mathbb{R} is a Lipschitz function with constant L>0ğ¿0L>0 if for any x,yâˆˆğ•Šdâˆ’1ğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1x,\,y\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1}

|fâ€‹(x)âˆ’fâ€‹(y)|â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–xâˆ’yâ€–2.ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ‘“ğ‘¦ğ¿subscriptnormğ‘¥ğ‘¦2|f(x)-f(y)|\leq L\|x-y\|_{2}.

The following result is a reformulation of Theorem 5.1.4 in Vershynin (2018) with explicit absolute constants.

Theorem 6

Let Xâˆˆğ•Šdâˆ’1ğ‘‹superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1X\in\mathbb{S}^{d-1} be a random vector uniformly distributed on the unit Euclidean sphere. If f:ğ•Šdâˆ’1â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptğ•Šğ‘‘1â„f\colon\mathbb{S}^{d-1}\to\mathbb{R} is Lâˆ’limit-fromğ¿L-Lipschitz function, then for any tâ‰¥0ğ‘¡0t\geq 0

Probâ€‹(|fâ€‹(X)âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹fâ€‹(X)|â‰¥t)â‰¤5â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’(dâˆ’2)â€‹t28â€‹L2).Probğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ”¼ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘¡5ğ‘‘2superscriptğ‘¡28superscriptğ¿2{\rm Prob}\left(|f(X)-\mathbb{E}f(X)|\geq t\right)\leq 5\exp\left(-\frac{(d-2)t^{2}}{8L^{2}}\right).

Informally and rather surprisingly, Lipschitz functions on a high-dimensional unit sphere are almost constants. Particularly, it implies that deviations of function values from the average are at most 8â€‹Ld8ğ¿ğ‘‘\frac{8L}{\sqrt{d}} with confidence level more than 0.99. We will apply this concentration inequality for the function xâ†’â€–Uâ€‹xâ€–2â†’ğ‘¥subscriptnormğ‘ˆğ‘¥2x\to\|Ux\|_{2} which is 1âˆ’limit-from11-Lipschitz if Uğ‘ˆU is orthogonal.

5.2 Random orthogonal matrices

Up to this point we did not discuss how to choose the frame vectors uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} or the frame matrix Uğ‘ˆU, which is used in the construction of Kashinâ€™s representation. We only know that it should be orthogonal and satisfy RIP for some parameters Î´,Î·ğ›¿ğœ‚\delta,\eta. We now describe how to construct frame matrix Uğ‘ˆU and how to estimate parameters Î´,Î·ğ›¿ğœ‚\delta,\eta. Unluckily, there is no an explicit construction scheme for such matrices. There are random generation processes that provide probabilistic guarantees (CandÃ¨s und Tao, 2005, 2006; Lyubarskii und Vershynin, 2010).

Consider random dÃ—Dğ‘‘ğ·d\times D matrices with orthonormal rows. Such matrices are obtained from selecting the first dğ‘‘d rows of orthogonal DÃ—Dğ·ğ·D\times D matrices. Let Oâ€‹(D)ğ‘‚ğ·O(D) be the space of all orthogonal DÃ—Dğ·ğ·D\times D matrices with the unique translation invariance and normalized measure, which is called Haar measure for that space. Then the space of dÃ—Dğ‘‘ğ·d\times D orthogonal matrices is

Oâ€‹(dÃ—D)={U=Pdâ€‹V:VâˆˆOâ€‹(D)},ğ‘‚ğ‘‘ğ·conditional-setğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ‘‚ğ·O(d\times D)=\{U=P_{d}V\colon V\in O(D)\},

where Pd:â„Dâ†’â„d:subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘â†’superscriptâ„ğ·superscriptâ„ğ‘‘P_{d}\colon\mathbb{R}^{D}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is the orthogonal projection on the first dğ‘‘d coordinates. The probability measure on Oâ€‹(dÃ—D)ğ‘‚ğ‘‘ğ·O(d\times D) is induces by the Haar measure on Oâ€‹(D)ğ‘‚ğ·O(D). Next we show that, with respect to the normalized Haar measure, randomly generated orthogonal matrices satisfy RIP with high probability. The following result is refinement of Theorem 4.1 in Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010).

Theorem 7

Let Î»>1ğœ†1\lambda>1 and D=Î»â€‹dğ·ğœ†ğ‘‘D=\lambda d, then with probability at least

1âˆ’5â€‹expâ¡[âˆ’dâ€‹(Î»âˆ’1)2â€‹(126+1208â€‹logâ¡(1âˆ’1Î»))],15ğ‘‘superscriptğœ†12126120811ğœ†1-5\exp\left[-d\left(\sqrt{\lambda}-1\right)^{2}\left(\frac{1}{26}+\frac{1}{208}\log\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{\lambda}}\right)\right)\right],

a random orthogonal dÃ—Dğ‘‘ğ·d\times D matrix Uğ‘ˆU satisfies RIP with parameters

Î·=34+14â‹…1Î»,Î´=154â€‹(1âˆ’1Î»)2.formulae-sequenceğœ‚34â‹…141ğœ†ğ›¿1superscript54superscript11ğœ†2\eta=\frac{3}{4}+\frac{1}{4}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{\lambda}},\qquad\delta=\frac{1}{5^{4}}\left(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{\lambda}}\right)^{2}. (13)

Note that the expression for the probability can be negative if Î»ğœ†\lambda is too close to 1. Specifically, the logarithmic term vanishes for Î»â‰ˆ1.0005ğœ†1.0005\lambda\approx 1.0005 giving negative probability. However, the probability approaches to 111 quite rapidly for bigger Î»ğœ†\lambdaâ€™s. To get a sense of how high that probability can be, note that for d=1000ğ‘‘1000d=1000 variables and Î»=2ğœ†2\lambda=2 inflation it is bigger than 0.980.980.98.

Now that we have explicit formulas for the parameters Î´ğ›¿\delta and Î·ğœ‚\eta, we can combine it with the results of Section 4 and summarize with the following theorem.

Theorem 8

Let Î»>1ğœ†1\lambda>1 be the redundancy factor and ğ’ğ’{\cal C} be any unbiased compression operator satisfying (12). Then Kashin Compression ğ’Îºâˆˆğ•Œâ€‹(Ï‰Î»)subscriptğ’ğœ…ğ•Œsubscriptğœ”ğœ†{\cal C}_{\kappa}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega_{\lambda}) is an unbiased compression with dimension independent variance

6 Experiments

In this section we describe the implementation details of KC and present our experiments of KC compared to other popular compression methods in the literature.

6.1 Implementation details of KC

To generate a random (fat) orthogonal frame matrix Uğ‘ˆU, we first generate a random matrix with entries drown independently from Gaussian distribution. Then we extract an orthogonal matrix by applying QR decomposition. Note that, for big dimensions the generation process of frame matrix Uğ‘ˆU becomes computationally expensive. However, after fixing the dimension of to-be-compressed vectors then the frame matrix needs to be generated only once and can be used throughout the learning process.

Afterwards, we turn to the estimation of the parameters Î´ğ›¿\delta and Î·ğœ‚\eta of RIP, which are necessary to compute Kashinâ€™s representations. These parameters are estimated iteratively so to minimize the representation level Kğ¾K (11) subject to the constraint (10) of RIP. For fixed Î´ğ›¿\delta we first find the least Î·ğœ‚\eta such 10 holds for unit vectors, which were obtained by normalizing Gaussian random vectors (we chose sample size of 104âˆ’105superscript104superscript10510^{4}-10^{5}, which provided a good estimate). Then we tune the parameter Î´ğ›¿\delta (initially chosen 0.90.90.9) to minimize the level Kğ¾K (11).

6.2 Empirical variance comparison

We empirically compare the variance produced by natural dithering (HorvÃ¡th u.â€‰a., 2019a) against KC with natural dithering and observe that latter introduces much less variance. We generated nğ‘›n vectors with dğ‘‘d independent entries from standard Gaussian distribution. Then we fix the minimum number of levels sğ‘ s that allows obtaining an acceptable variance for performing KC with natural dithering. Next, we adjust levels sğ‘ s for natural dithering to the almost same number of bits used for transmission of the compressed vector. For each of these vectors we compute normalized empirical variance via

Ï‰â€‹(x)â‰”â€–ğ’â€‹(x)âˆ’xâ€–2â€–xâ€–2.â‰”ğœ”ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥2superscriptnormğ‘¥2\omega(x)\coloneqq\frac{\|\mathcal{C}(x)-x\|^{2}}{\|x\|^{2}}. (15)

In FigureÂ 2 we provide boxplots for empirical variances, which show that the increase of parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda leads to smaller variance for KC. They also confirm that for natural dithering, the variance Ï‰ğœ”\omega scales with the dimension dğ‘‘d while for KC that scaling is significantly reduced (see also Table 1 for variance bounds). This shows the positive effect of KC combined with other compression methods. For additional insights, we present also swarmplots provided by Seaborn Library. FigureÂ 3 illustrates the strong robustness property of KC with respect to outliers.

6.3 Minimizing quadratics with CGD

To illustrate the advantages of KC in optimization algorithms, we minimized randomly generated quadratic functions (16) for d=104ğ‘‘superscript104d=10^{4} using gradient descent with compressed gradients.

minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡fâ€‹(x)=12â€‹xâŠ¤â€‹Aâ€‹xâˆ’bâŠ¤â€‹x,subscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥12superscriptğ‘¥topğ´ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘topğ‘¥\min\limits_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}~{}~{}f(x)=\frac{1}{2}x^{\top}Ax-b^{\top}x, (16)

In FigureÂ 4(a) we evaluate functional suboptimality

fâ€‹(xk)âˆ’fâˆ—fâ€‹(x0)âˆ’fâˆ—ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘“ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥0superscriptğ‘“\frac{f(x_{k})-f^{*}}{f(x_{0})-f^{*}}

in log-scale for vertical axis. These plots illustrate the superiority of KC with ternary quantization, where it does not degrade the convergence at all and saves in communication compared to other compression methods and without any compression scheme.

To provide more insights into this setting, FigureÂ 4(b) visualizes empirical variances of the compressed gradients throughout the optimization process, revealing both the low variance feature and the stabilization property of KC.

6.4 Minimizing quadratics with distributed CGD

Consider the minimization problem of the average of nğ‘›n quadratics

minxâˆˆâ„dâ¡fâ€‹(x)â‰”1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nfiâ€‹(x),wherefiâ€‹(x)=12â€‹xâŠ¤â€‹Aiâ€‹x,formulae-sequenceâ‰”subscriptğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ‘¥1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥wheresubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥12superscriptğ‘¥topsubscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ‘¥\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(x)\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x),\qquad\text{where}\qquad f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{2}x^{\top}A_{i}x, (17)

with synthetically generated matrices Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}. We solve this problem with Distributed Compressed Gradient Descent (AlgorithmÂ 2) using a selection of compression operators.

FiguresÂ 5 andÂ 6 show that KC combined with ternary quantization leads to faster convergence and uses less bits to communicate than ternary quantization alone. Note that in higher dimension the gap between KC with ternary quantization and no compression gets smaller in the iteration plot, while in the communication plot it gets bigger. So, in high dimensions KC convergences slightly worse than no compression scheme, but the savings in communication are huge.

A.2 Proof of Theorem 1: Derivation from Rate Distortion Theory

After the first online appearance of the work, we had been aware of by an anonymous reviewer that this result follows from the rate distortion theory. We include the derivation here.

Here we deduce the lower bound (3) from the results of rate distortion theory, which is a subfield of information theory (Cover und Thomas, 2006). Rate distortion theory describes theoretical limitations of lossy compression of a given random variable in terms of information rate Rğ‘…R and distortion threshold Dğ·D. In our notation, the rate R=b/dğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘‘R=\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}} is the average number of bits over coordinates and distortion D=Î±â€‹Ïƒ2ğ·ğ›¼superscriptğœ2D=\alpha\sigma^{2}, where Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} is the variance of the random variable. Rate distortion function Râ€‹(D)ğ‘…ğ·R(D) of a given random source is the minimal rate to transfer an i.i.d. sample such that the receiver can decode the initial sequence with distortion Dğ·D. We assume that squared error distortion measure is used, namely

Ïâ€‹(x,x^)=1dâ€‹âˆ‘i=1d(xiâˆ’x^i)2.ğœŒğ‘¥^ğ‘¥1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–2\rho(x,\hat{x})=\frac{1}{d}\sum_{i=1}^{d}(x_{i}-\hat{x}_{i})^{2}.

This distortion measure is particularly convenient for our setup as inequality (2) can be written as

ğ”¼ğ’â€‹[Ïâ€‹(ğ’â€‹(x),x)]â‰¤Î±â€‹Ïâ€‹(x,0),xâˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ”¼ğ’delimited-[]ğœŒğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ›¼ğœŒğ‘¥0ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C}}\left[\rho({\cal C}(x),x)\right]\leq\alpha\rho(x,0),\quad x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}. (21)

If (21) holds uniformly for any xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, then it also holds in expectation with respect to xâˆ¼ğ’Ÿsimilar-toğ‘¥ğ’Ÿx\sim{\cal D} with i.i.d. coordinates sampled from some distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}:

ğ”¼ğ’,ğ’Ÿâ€‹[Ïâ€‹(ğ’â€‹(x),x)]â‰¤Î±â€‹ğ”¼ğ’Ÿâ€‹[Ïâ€‹(x,0)]=Î±â€‹Ïƒ2=D,xâˆ¼ğ’Ÿ.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ”¼ğ’ğ’Ÿdelimited-[]ğœŒğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ›¼subscriptğ”¼ğ’Ÿdelimited-[]ğœŒğ‘¥0ğ›¼superscriptğœ2ğ·similar-toğ‘¥ğ’Ÿ\mathbb{E}_{{\cal C},{\cal D}}\left[\rho({\cal C}(x),x)\right]\leq\alpha\mathbb{E}_{{\cal D}}\left[\rho(x,0)\right]=\alpha\sigma^{2}=D,\quad x\sim{\cal D}.

This implies that the rate Rğ‘…R of compression ğ’ğ’{\cal C} is bigger than rate distortion function Râ€‹(D)ğ‘…ğ·R(D) for any distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}. In particular, Râ‰¥Rğ’©â€‹(D)ğ‘…subscriptğ‘…ğ’©ğ·R\geq R_{{\cal N}}(D) when distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} is Gaussian. It is known that rate distortion function Rğ’©â€‹(D)subscriptğ‘…ğ’©ğ·R_{\mathcal{N}}(D) for Gaussian random variable can be written analytically as

Rğ’©â€‹(D)={log4â¡Ïƒ2Dif0â‰¤Dâ‰¤Ïƒ20ifD>Ïƒ2.subscriptğ‘…ğ’©ğ·casessubscript4superscriptğœ2ğ·if0ğ·superscriptğœ20ifğ·superscriptğœ2R_{{\cal N}}(D)=\begin{cases}\log_{4}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{D}&\text{if}\quad 0\leq D\leq\sigma^{2}\\ 0&\text{if}\quad D>\sigma^{2}.\end{cases}

Translating inequality Râ‰¥Rğ’©â€‹(D)ğ‘…subscriptğ‘…ğ’©ğ·R\geq R_{{\cal N}}(D) into the language of Î±=D/Ïƒ2âˆˆ[0,1]ğ›¼ğ·superscriptğœ201\alpha=\nicefrac{{D}}{{\sigma^{2}}}\in[0,1] and b=Râ€‹dğ‘ğ‘…ğ‘‘b=Rd, we get Î±â‹…4b/dâ‰¥1â‹…ğ›¼superscript4ğ‘ğ‘‘1\alpha\cdot 4^{\nicefrac{{b}}{{d}}}\geq 1.

It is worth to mention that Gaussian random variable is the hardest source to encode, meaning it requires the most number of bits to ensure a given distortion constraint. Formally, for any random variable with the same Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} variance the rate distortion function Râ€‹(D)â‰¤Rğ’©â€‹(D)ğ‘…ğ·subscriptğ‘…ğ’©ğ·R(D)\leq R_{{\cal N}}(D).

Remark 1

In practice we do not deal with too large or too small values because of the finite bit representation of a single float in a machine. Therefore, the quantifier âˆ€xâˆˆâ„dfor-allğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\forall x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} in (2) or (21) and the idealized Gaussian source used for the lower bound should be relaxed by excluding vectors with too small or too large norms and considering approximate Gaussian distributions.

A.3 Proof of Lemma 1

Let ğ’âˆˆğ•Œâ€‹(Ï‰)ğ’ğ•Œğœ”\mathcal{C}\in\mathbb{U}(\omega). Using relations ğ”¼â€‹[ğ’â€‹(x)]=xğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥\mathbb{E}\left[{\cal C}(x)\right]=x and ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’â€‹(x)â€–2]â‰¤(Ï‰+1)â€‹â€–xâ€–2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ’ğ‘¥2ğœ”1superscriptnormğ‘¥2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|{\cal C}(x)\right\|^{2}\right]\leq(\omega+1)\|x\|^{2}, we get

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–1Ï‰+1â€‹ğ’â€‹(x)âˆ’xâ€–2]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnorm1ğœ”1ğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\frac{1}{\omega+1}\mathcal{C}(x)-x\right\|^{2}\right] =1(Ï‰+1)2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’â€‹(x)â€–2]âˆ’2Ï‰+1â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[âŸ¨ğ’â€‹(x),xâŸ©]+â€–xâ€–2absent1superscriptğœ”12ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ’ğ‘¥22ğœ”1ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ’ğ‘¥ğ‘¥superscriptnormğ‘¥2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{(\omega+1)^{2}}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)\|^{2}\right]-\frac{2}{\omega+1}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\langle\mathcal{C}(x),x\right\rangle\right]+\|x\|^{2}
=1(Ï‰+1)2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’â€‹(x)â€–2]+(âˆ’2Ï‰+1+1)â€‹â€–xâ€–2absent1superscriptğœ”12ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ’ğ‘¥22ğœ”11superscriptnormğ‘¥2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{(\omega+1)^{2}}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathcal{C}(x)\|^{2}\right]+\left(-\frac{2}{\omega+1}+1\right)\|x\|^{2}
â‰¤(1Ï‰+1âˆ’2Ï‰+1+1)â€‹â€–xâ€–2=Ï‰Ï‰+1â€‹â€–xâ€–2,absent1ğœ”12ğœ”11superscriptnormğ‘¥2ğœ”ğœ”1superscriptnormğ‘¥2\displaystyle\leq\left(\frac{1}{\omega+1}-\frac{2}{\omega+1}+1\right)\|x\|^{2}=\frac{\omega}{\omega+1}\|x\|^{2},

which concludes the lemma.

Appendix B Proof for Section 3

B.1 Proof of Theorem 3: Asymptotic tightness of UP

We use the construction of Kochol (1994), which states the following:

Theorem 9 (Kochol (1994))

For any dimension dâ‰¥1ğ‘‘1d\geq 1 and any fixed 2â€‹dâ‰¤mâ‰¤2d2ğ‘‘ğ‘šsuperscript2ğ‘‘2d\leq m\leq 2^{d} there exist mğ‘šm unit vectors such that the convex hull of them (or the polytope with such vertices) contains a ball of radius

c1â€‹1dâ€‹logâ¡md,subscriptğ‘11ğ‘‘ğ‘šğ‘‘c_{1}\sqrt{\frac{1}{d}\log\frac{m}{d}},

Appendix C Proofs for Section 5

Proofs presented in this section are adjustments of several standard and classical techniques. We present the proofs here to find out hidden absolute constants.

C.2 Proof of Theorem 7: Random orthogonal matrices with RIP

Most of the proof follows the steps of the proof of Theorem 4.1 of Lyubarskii und Vershynin (2010). First, we relax the inequality in Theorem 6 to

Probâ€‹(|fâ€‹(X)âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹fâ€‹(X)|â‰¥t)â‰¤5â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’dâ€‹t29â€‹L2),tâ‰¥0,dâ‰¥20.formulae-sequenceProbğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ”¼ğ‘“ğ‘‹ğ‘¡5ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘¡29superscriptğ¿2formulae-sequenceğ‘¡0ğ‘‘20{\rm Prob}\left(|f(X)-\mathbb{E}f(X)|\geq t\right)\leq 5\exp\left(-\frac{d\,t^{2}}{9L^{2}}\right),\quad t\geq 0,\,d\geq 20. Let xâˆˆğ•ŠDâˆ’1ğ‘¥superscriptğ•Šğ·1x\in\mathbb{S}^{D-1} be fixed. Any orthogonal dÃ—Dğ‘‘ğ·d\times D matrix UâˆˆOâ€‹(dÃ—D)ğ‘ˆğ‘‚ğ‘‘ğ·U\in O(d\times D) can be represented as the projection U=Pdâ€‹Vğ‘ˆsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘‘ğ‘‰U=P_{d}V of DÃ—Dğ·ğ·D\times D orthogonal matrix VâˆˆOâ€‹(D)ğ‘‰ğ‘‚ğ·V\in O(D). The uniform probability measure (or Haar measure) on Oâ€‹(D)ğ‘‚ğ·O(D) ensures that if VâˆˆOâ€‹(D)ğ‘‰ğ‘‚ğ·V\in O(D) is random then the vector z=Vâ€‹xğ‘§ğ‘‰ğ‘¥z=Vx is uniformly distributed on ğ•ŠDâˆ’1superscriptğ•Šğ·1\mathbb{S}^{D-1}.
